The best way to approach such a question is by analyzing the cases of the variables. For this question there are 4 such cases.

Case 1: $$a \geq 0$$ and $$b \geq 0$$ 

Case 2: $$a \leq 0$$ and $$b \leq 0$$

Case 3: $$a \geq 0$$ and $$b \leq 0$$

Case 4: $$a \leq 0$$ and $$b \geq 0$$

Good luck!

Question:
Triangle Inequality Proof Question:

Hello, I have a question about the approach we used to prove the Triangle Inequality in 1 dimension on the first day of class. In our proof, for a 1d triangle abc, we assumed a < b, then did 3 cases, each assuming c to be in a different interval (either c < a < b or a < c < b or a < b < c), then demonstrating the inequality for |a-b| $$\leq$$ |c-b| + |a-c| is true in each case. Would it also be valid a method for proving to assume the 1d  triangle abc has a < b < c, then demonstrating

|a-b| $$\leq$$ |a-c| + |b-c|,

|a-c| $$\leq$$ |a-b| + |b-c|,

and |b-c| $$\leq$$ |a-b| + |a-c|?

Would this be a valid method for proving the triangle inequality?
Answer: I'm not quite sure if I understand the question, but once we've proven the triangle inequality then we can replace the variables in the expression to derive any other equivalent expression. The three equations you've written look like the original $$|x-z| \leq |x-y| + |y-z|$$ but with the variables $$x,y,z$$ replaced with different combinations of $$a,b,c$$.

Question: Question about the triangle inequality: In the triangle inequality, I'm slightly confused as to why it is assumed that x < y. Why is this assumption needed for the proof to be valid? Would appreciate an explanation. Thanks!
Answer:
If x=y then |x-y|=0. Since we are trying to prove that |x-y| is smaller or equal to |y-z| + |z-y|, 0 is smaller or equal than any |y-z| + |z-y| (i.e. the right side of the inequality cannot be negative). This means we do not have to worry about x=y.

Furthermore, since |x-y| = |y-x|, they are kind of interchangeable (meaning if you cover x<y, you also cover x>y).

Thus, we can continue the proof assuming x<y without loss of generality.

Note that by assuming x<y, we aren't making the proof valid, but rather, we are noting that we already are covering the other scenarios (x=y or x>y).

If x=y then |x-y|=0. Since we are trying to prove that |x-y| is smaller or equal to |y-z| + |z-y|, 0 is smaller or equal than any |y-z| + |z-y| (i.e. the right side of the inequality cannot be negative). This means we do not have to worry about x=y.

Furthermore, since |x-y| = |y-x|, they are kind of interchangeable (meaning if you cover x<y, you also cover x>y).

Thus, we can continue the proof assuming x<y without loss of generality.

Question:
How do I get faster at this??:

Hi, this isn't really a math question, but more so an overall university question.

How do I prepare myself to write a quiz in 35 minutes, especially when sometimes it takes me 35 minutes to answer a question on Mobius or on the practice quizzes? 

I'm wondering if I'm missing any techniques to get faster at these- are there any tricks that make these questions easier? for example, question 3 on Practice Quiz 1... is there a way to correctly answer this without breaking up and solving all the possible cases? 

 I'm just feeling super discouraged and stressed :(
Answer:
Generally, you need to do lots of practice in order to get more familiar and able to solve more quickly.

For MC3, the fastest way is to think about the problem geometrically: $$1\leq |x-5| < 3$$ means the set of points that are 1 or more units from 5 AND less than 3 units away. So, looking at the number line, this suggests the set $$(2,4]\cup [6,8)$$.

For writing quizzes, some general advice is to read through the entirety of the quiz first and then start with the long answers. These questions are worth the most and have part marks. From there, you can work backwards to the short answers, MCs and TFs.

EDIT: Sorry, I forgot the most important thing: You can do this; you would not have been accepted to UWaterloo if there was doubt about your capabilities.

Question:
Will we need to remember proofs?:

On quizzes and exams, will we need to show the proof that a theorem derives from or just remember the theorem? Additionally, will we need to prove new things that we never learned?
Answer:
There shouldn't be any questions about proving the theorem taught in class in the quiz. We assume you know the theorem and its proof.

You also won't be asked to prove anything that are outside of the scope of the quiz material in the quiz. However, there might be some proof questions related to the current or past quiz material. i.e. practice problem q2.

With that being said, no, you don't need to memorize the exact proof of the theorem, but it's important & recommended to know how the theorems are derived.

Question: Week 1 Outline Q2 a) help: I have been trying to solve Question 2 a) from the outline of week 1. I checked the solution after trying and I see that they use the triangle inequality. However I do not understand how they used the triangle inequality to get the new inequality created in step 2. If anyone could help explain that would be great!
Answer:
@18

For any triangle ABC, let the length of side A = |a|, the length of side B = |b|, and the length of side C = |a - b| (since the absolute value of a difference is like the distance between those 2 points).

|a - b| ≤ |a| + |b|,

|a| ≤ |a - b| + |b|,

 and |b| ≤ |a| + |a - b|

all must be true because they ARE the triangle inequality.

for the question

|a| − |b| ≤ |a − b|

is the same as

|a| ≤ |a − b| + |b|

which is identical to the second triangle inequality above.

for the question

|a| − |b| ≤ |a + b|

since |b| = |-b|

|a| − |b| ≤ |a + b|

is the same as

|a| − |-b| ≤ |a - (-b)|

is the same as

|a| ≤ |a - (-b)| + |-b|

and the solution is the same as above.

Question:
Week 1 Practice Quiz: A Single Interval:

Hello!

One of the questions in the Week 1 Practice Quiz asks us whether an inequality can be expressed as a single open interval (I've attached the Mobius solution below for context).

I wanted to ask for clarification on two aspects of the solution: First, why do we claim that for a single open interval to exist, $$(-b + 2, b+2)$$ must intersect with exactly one of the previous 2 intervals? Does $$(-b + 2, b+2)$$ ranging from the middle of the first to the middle of the second interval not leave us with a single open interval?

I'm also wondering how we determine the 2 cases at the bottom. When I drew out a mock-number line, I initially thought that $$ -b+2 < -a+2$$ in case 1, and $$a+2 < b+2$$ in case 2 for "overlap" to occur. I'm not quite sure I'm seeing why both cases use the opposite inequalities.

Thank you!
Answer:
To answer your question,
1, if (-b+2, b+2) intersect both, you will have two disconnected interval. That is due to the previous 2 intervals are not connected, thus the intersection of (-b+2, b+2) and those previous two intervals will also be disconnected.
2, The reason those two cases are opposite inequalities in the feedback, is because the cases they put are when intersection of those two sets are empty set. So in this case, we do not want overlap to occur.

Question:
Week 1 Important Inequality Confusion:

From lec 1 video

$$0<|x-a|<\delta$$ if and only if $$x\epsilon (a-\delta, a+\delta) /$${a}

Why is a not a real solution to this? The previous important equality without the 0 < did not contain the /{a}. I am unsure on how making the inequality greater than zero removes a from the solution set.
Answer:
Lets substitute in values to each variable to see why

Let δ = 5

let a = 3

0 < |x-a| < δ

0 < |x-3| < 5

if x is 3 than we have

0 < 0 < 5 which is not true

if the 0 was a different value, for example purposes lets say 1

then we will have an interval of values from (a-1,a+1) or (2,4)

1 < |2-3| < 5 

1 < 1 < 5

hopefully that helps

That is because the distance from a is 0. Remember, absolute value |x-a| is the distance from x to a. If x=a  then the distance is 0. Therefore, in order for 0 < |x-a| < $$\delta$$ to be true, you have to exclude a. Hope this helps!

Question:
Week 2 Practice Question Mathmatize Q4 (from Lecture 3):
I don't really understand why N should be > 1/e...

I tried doing it the way we were taught in class, where we sort of just move our variables around
1/(N^2 + 1) < e
1/e < N^2 + 1
1/e - 1 < N^2
sqrt(1/e - 1) < N

And I wasn't really sure why that wasn't an option. Could someone help me out?
Answer:
Yep that would also be fine. It just so happens that $$\frac{1}{\epsilon} > \sqrt{\frac{1}{\epsilon} - 1}$$ so that the choice given in the question is just "easier" but not necessarily the "best".

Remember that once you find a cutoff that works then any other cutoff AFTER that is also valid.

Small detail here is that the choice $$N = \sqrt{\frac{1}{\epsilon} - 1}$$ restricts $$\epsilon$$ to being 1 or smaller when technically it should be allowed to be any number. The "fix" for that is to realize that if $$\epsilon$$ is bigger than 1 then because the sequence is given by $$\frac{1}{n^2 + 1}$$ and $$n \geq 1$$ the distance from $$\frac{1}{n^2 + 1}$$ to $$0$$ is already smaller than $$1$$ for all $$n$$.

Question:
Practice quiz proof:

How would we prove this? I saw someone else asked but I don't think there was an answer. 

||x| − |y|| ≤ |x − y| for all x, y ∈ R
Answer:
20230911_223000.jpg The basic idea of students' answer is correct. You separate ||x| − |y|| into two cases: |x| − |y| >= 0 and |x| − |y| < 0. Then acquire |x-y| = |y-x| then the rest of the proof is basically equivalent to practice problem 2a).
 
However, there are some issues, as |x| - |y| DOES NOT EQUAL TO |x-y|. same for |y-x| case. Counter example: x = -5, y = 6, |x| - |y| = -1 and |x-y| = 11.

Remember, there is a reason why triangle inequality is called triangle "inequality" :)) . It never guarantees an equal.

Question:
Week 1 Practice Problem 3:

How does 1/2(a + b + |a-b| ) computes the maximum of a and b while 1/2(a + b - |a-b| ) computes the minimum of a and b? And What does that mean?
Answer:
For 1/2 (a + b + |a - b|)

There are two cases that apply to this expression:

1. a >= b, for which |a - b| evaluates to (a - b)

2. b > a, for which |a - b| evaluates to -(a - b) => (b - a)

if a >= b,  => 1/2 (a + b + a - b) => 1/2(2a) => a

   As you can see, when a >= b, the function returns a, which is also the maximum of a and b

Similarly

if a < b, => 1/2 (a + b - a + b) => 1/2(2b) => b

   As you can see for this case, when a < b, the function returns b, which is also the maximum of a and b

Try applying the same process to see how 1/2 (a + b - |a - b|) computes the minimum of a and b

Hope that helped :)

Question: Clarification on Intersection and Union: I've been working on the practice quiz and was wondering if there anyone had a way to explain the difference between the ∩ and the ∪ symbols. I can't seem to wrap my brain around these two symbols and their meaning
Answer:
Say you have 2 sets of numbers, A and B. 
A ∩ B refers to the "intersection" of the sets. In English, it means "in both A AND B".

Ex. if you have A {2, 4, 5} and B {3, 4, 5}, A ∩ B is {4, 5}. 4 and 5 are the only numbers which are in both A and B.
if you have intervals C (-2, 4) and D (3, 7), C ∩ D is the interval (3, 4) because that is where those sets intersect/overlap. 

A ∪ B refers to the "union" of the sets. 
In English, it means "in A OR B", which includes numbers which are in both A and B. 

Ex. if you have A {2, 4, 5} and B {3, 4, 5}, A ∪ B is {2, 3, 4, 5}. All of those numbers are in A, or B, or both.
if you have intervals C (-2, 4) and D (3, 7), C ∪ D is the interval (-2, 7) because all the values within can be found in C, or D, or both. 

You can remember which is which with "U  for Union", as the union symbol ∪ looks like a U.
Say you have 2 sets of numbers, A and B. 
A ∩ B refers to the "intersection" of the sets. In English, it means "in both A AND B".

Ex. if you have A {2, 4, 5} and B {3, 4, 5}, A ∩ B is {4, 5}. 4 and 5 are the only numbers which are in both A and B.
if you have intervals C (-2, 4) and D (3, 7), C ∩ D is the interval (3, 4) because that is where those sets intersect/overlap. 

A ∪ B refers to the "union" of the sets. 
In English, it means "in A OR B", which includes numbers which are in both A and B. 

Ex. if you have A {2, 4, 5} and B {3, 4, 5}, A ∪ B is {2, 3, 4, 5}. All of those numbers are in A, or B, or both.
if you have intervals C (-2, 4) and D (3, 7), C ∪ D is the interval (-2, 7) because all the values within can be found in C, or D, or both. 

You can remember which is which with "U  for Union", as that symbol looks like the first letter.

Question: Theorem of Limit: What does it mean by “all but finitely many terms”? As the tail of {an} contains infinite terms, then how does the interval (L-epsilon, L+epsilon) contains finite terms.
Answer:
“all but finitely many terms” means all terms excluding some terms. The interval $$(L-\epsilon , L+\epsilon )$$ has infinite number of terms.

I will demonstrate this through an example. Say we have $$a_{1} = 1, a_{n} = \frac{1}{n}, \lim_{n->\infty} a_{n} = 0$$. Let's say $$\epsilon = 0.1$$. Then the interval $$(L-\epsilon , L+\epsilon )$$ does contain all terms but {$$a_{1}, a_{2}, ... , a_{10}$$}. The terms which are excluded are finite.

Question: Quiz 1 confusion: can someone please explain why we have a range till infinity for a and not for b?
Answer:
We have:

a < |x - 6| < b

This can be split up into:

a < |x - 6|

AND

|x - 6| < b

Taking a look at these individually:

1) |x - 6| < b

This statement is looking for values of "x", whos distance to "6" is less than "b".

There are only a finite set of "x" values for any given "b" value since we are restricting the distance between "x" and "6" to LESS than "b" units.

2) a < |x - 6|

However, here we are looking for an "x" value, whos distance to "6" is larger than "a".

Given that we are we are restricting the distance between "x" and "6" to MORE than "a" units, we are left with an infinite amount of values which satisfy this inequality.

An easier way to think about it is as follows:

For our purposes imagine that we are only working with natural numbers.

You are asked to find all values that are less than 5.

Those being: 1, 2, 3, and 4.

However, if you were asked to determine all numbers greater than five,

You would have: 6, 7, 8, 9, 10... ∞.

Infinite possibilities.

Hope this helps.

Question:
Extra Practice Chapter 2:

I came across a question where it asked to calculate the limit as n $$\rightarrow$$ $$\infty$$ ($$n^{2}|cosn\pi|$$)

How would we go about this? I
Answer:
Just want to note that $$cosn\pi$$ can be ambiguous, as it can be interpreted as (cosn)$$\pi$$ or $$cos(n\pi)$$ and those two are different. I will interpret it as $$cos(n\pi)$$ in this case.

For the sequence of $$a_n=n^2|cos(n\pi)|$$, $$\lim_{n->\infty} a_n = \infty$$. This is because when n is odd, $$cos(n\pi)$$ = -1, and when n is even, $$cos(n\pi$$) =1. But because $$cos(n\pi)$$ is inside absolute value sign, the sequence becomes $$a_n=n^2(1) = n^2$$, which diverges to infinity following the theorem.

However, if we are talking about the function instead of the sequence, then the limit does not exist.  This is currently outside of the scope of week 2 material, formal proof for limit of functions will be taught later this course. However, you are always welcome to attempt this :)

Just want to note that $$cosn\pi$$ can be ambiguous, as it can be interpreted as (cosn)$$\pi$$ or $$cos(n\pi)$$ and those two are different. I will interpret it as $$cos(n\pi)$$ in this case.

For the sequence of $$a_n=n^2|cos(n\pi)|$$, $$\lim_{n->\infty} a_n = \infty$$. This is because when n is odd, $$cos(n\pi)$$ = -1, and when n is even, $$cos(n\pi$$) =1. But because $$cos(n\pi)$$ is inside absolute value sign, the sequence becomes $$a_n=n^2|1| = n^2$$, which diverges to infinity following the theorem.

However, if we are talking about the function instead of the sequence, then the limit does not exist.  This is currently outside of the scope of week 2 material, formal proof for limit of functions will be taught later this course. However, you are always welcome to attempt this :)

Question:
Extra Practice Chapter 2:

How did the values after $$\frac{1}{n^{2}+1}$$ get obtained?
Answer:
In order to prove the limit = 0, we need $$ \frac{1}{n^2+1} < \epsilon$$. How do we get to there?

Okay, Note that $$n^2+1 > n^2$$, then we can get $$\frac{1}{n^2+1} < \frac{1}{n^2}$$. Also because $$\forall n\in \mathbb{N}$$, $$n \leq n^2$$, then $$\frac{1}{n^2} \leq \frac{1}{n}$$. 

We know that $$n\geq N$$, then $$\frac{1}{n} \leq \frac{1}{N}$$.
Similar logic, we know that $$N > \frac{1}{\epsilon}$$, then $$\frac{1}{N} < \epsilon$$.
By connecting those together, you will get the inequality in the screenshot. :)

M represents some cutoff value, when trying to prove that the limit goes to negative infinity, we need to prove that for that cutoff value, all the other values approach negative infinity. Question:
Week 2 Practice Problem 3 Don't understand the solution:

Anyone can please explain this? Especially the red part. Thank you so much.
Answer:
Hi! Let's recall that epsilon is any value that is greater than 0. Now, our sequence is 1(when perfect square) or 1/n (when anything else). To prove this, we will use a contradiction. We can pick any value for epsilon(this is important to know that we can pick any value for epsilon as long it is more than 0). 

Proof:

Let epsilon = 1/2. $$a_n$$ is 1 when n is a perfect square(eg. 4, 9), otherwise it is 1/n. 

Here is a sketch of what would happen.

We need to find a cutoff point N, after which the y-value is always in between (-epsilon, epsilon). That is impossible since there are infinitely many perfect squares. Thus, it would create a y-value of 1. Since 1>1/2(epsilon), we found a contradiction.

Hope this helps!!!

Question:
Questions about the formal definition of Limit:

Im so confused about what happen in here?

why $$n > 1/\in ^2$$? but not $$n < 1/\in ^2$$

We had similar cases like this during the lectures.

So, your initial inequality is: |1/$$\sqrt n$$ - 0| < epsilon

Drop the absolute value brackets(function is always positive) and solve for n

1/$$\sqrt n < \epsilon$$, then $$1/e < \sqrt n$$. Finally, $$1/\epsilon^2 < n$$

Therefore, we get n>N

Question:
Proof of Uniqueness of Limits for Sequences:
How does “at least one term must be in both intervals” come from?
Answer:
If you read further, it says that intervals are disjoint. Remember, for a limit to exist, a sequence (precisely, a tail of a sequence) needs to converge to some L or M. We know that tail is infinite in this case. However, some finite values omitted from the beginning of a sequence(eg.  if $$a_n = \{1, 2, 3, 4 ... n\}$$, a tail could be {5, 6, 7, 8 ... n}). So, if limits are not unique, you would find at least one value of a tail that is in both intervals after a cutoff point. This can't be true since limit intervals are disjoint.

The book explanation is a bit complicated:

Think of it like this:

FOr a limit to exist, there should be a tail that converges to some value after a cutoff(in other words - forever). It simply can't converge to two different values at the same time. 

I hope this isn't too complicated!

Question:
Practice Problem 2 Question 6 Case 2:

Hi guys, I am confused about the missing √An in the denominator as the (√An+√L) just turned into √L and there is no clarification or any sort of explanation, thanks.
How was this obtained for question 6 in the extra practice: ?
Answer:
Remember epsilon is arbituary. Which means, if $$\lim_{n->\infty} a_n = L$$, not only you can find N which $$|a_n-L|< \epsilon$$, you can also find N which $$|a_n-L|< x \epsilon$$ where $$x > 0$$.

Now we want to prove $$\lim_{n->\infty} \sqrt a_n = \sqrt L$$. Which means, we want $$|\sqrt a_n - \sqrt L|< \epsilon$$. So, what value of x in $$|a_n-L|< x \epsilon$$  we need to make this inequality work ?

Question:
ARITHMETIC RULES FOR LIMITS 8,9 question:

这是 n 常数吗？在这个等式中，它存在什么？我有点无法理解这两个公式代表什么
Answer:
It means for the degree of n greater than 0, limit of that sequence will always be infinity.
i.e. $$\lim_{n->\infty} n^2 = \infty$$

Oppositely, if the degree of n is less than 0, limit of that sequence will always be 0. i.e. $$\lim_{n->\infty} n^{-2} = \frac{1}{n^2} = 0$$

Note that in 8) and 9), $$\alpha$$ is a constant.

Question:
Practice Quiz Week 2 LA:

Hi, I am wondering about why the √an on the denominator disappear. Thank you for your time!
Answer: the denominator disappears because $$\frac{|a_n-L|}{\sqrt{a_n}+\sqrt{L}} <\frac{|a_n-L|}{\sqrt{L}}$$ This is because the question states that $$\forall n \in \mathbb{N}, (a_n>0) \implies \sqrt{a_n}>0$$, meaning that $$\sqrt{a_n}+\sqrt{L}>\sqrt{L}$$ for the denominators. If you are dividing a number by a bigger number, you will have a smaller number in the end (ex. 5/3 > 5/4). $$\sqrt{a_n}+\sqrt{L}$$ is bigger than $$\sqrt{L}$$, leading to the conclusion that $$\frac{|a_n-L|}{\sqrt{a_n}+\sqrt{L}} <\frac{|a_n-L|}{\sqrt{L}}$$.

Question: why the aside is 2/N^N:
Answer:
why the aside is 2/N^N <E but not 2/(N^N +4)< E

I did a "trick:" $$\dfrac{4}{2N^2 + 8} < \dfrac{4}{2N^2}$$ and then did the aside.

Note this isn't necessary: you could do the aside with $$\dfrac{2}{N^2+4} < \epsilon$$. There's nothing wrong with this, it just gives a somewhat uglier $$N$$.

Question: definition about an: When can we assume {an} is a sequence of natural numbers? if not why does the definition of limit indicate that N belongs to natural numbers?
Answer: the definition of the limit says that $$N \in \mathbb{N}$$ because N represents a term of the sequence. for example, if i had the sequence $$\{ 2,4,6,8,...\}$$ then 2 would be the first term, 4 would be the second term, and so on. It doesn't make sense to have a term that is not a natural number. For example, there is no -2 term of a sequence or no 0.2 term of a sequence. Since N represents a term of the sequence, it must be a natural number. Whether or not $$\{ a_n\}$$ is a sequence of natural numbers depends on the function that defines the sequence. if $$a_n=n$$, the sequence will just be 1,2,3,4,... and the sequence will consist of only natural numbers ($$f:n\rightarrow \mathbb{N}$$). if $$a_n=\frac{1}{n}$$, the sequence will be $$1, 1/2, 1/3, ...$$ and will not just consist of natural numbers ($$f:n\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$).

Question:
Mobius Question:

How are we supposed to solve this question? Isolating n takes a long time, and so does substituting the answers into the equation. What is the intended solution?
Answer:
@187 @159

Basically, you're supposed to solve it like a quadratic. You end up getting a quadratic like "εn² + (ε-2)n - 1 > 0".

Note that, if you imagine a parabola in your head, there are two areas where εn² + (ε-2)n - 1 > 0 (we will deal with this later).

Plug into the quadratic formula.

$$\frac{\sqrt{\epsilon^2+4)}-\epsilon + 2}{2\epsilon}$$

Note that we get two solutions, the positive square root, and the negative square root. The negative square root is extraneous (we know that the negative solution is less than 0 using the geometric fact that the hypotenuse is the longest side of a triangle i.e. $$\sqrt{\epsilon^2+2^2} > 2$$ so $$\sqrt{\epsilon^2+2^2} > 2-\epsilon$$, and $$n \geq 1$$ so negative solution is not possible).

Then you can basically just cross out incorrect answers (need answers of N that are greater than $$\frac{\sqrt{\epsilon^2+4)}-\epsilon + 2}{2\epsilon}$$).

This is a bit of a longer question so don't worry too much if it takes a while.

Question:
Lecture 8 Question:

Why do we pick the right side of the inequality? x+5<15
Answer:
Because to get to x+5, you need to add 7 to x-2 and on both sides of that inequality. So -8+7 < x-2+7 < 8+7 = 15
Because to get to x+5, you need to add 7 to x+2 and on both sides of that inequality. So -8+7 < x-2+7 < 8+7 = 15

Question:
Week 3 Practice Problems Q1:

In Q1 for Week 3's Practice Problems, the intended solution applies squeeze theorem to $$a_n \text{sin}(n) + b_n \text{cos}(n)$$ as a whole.

Instead, are we allowed to use squeeze theorem for $$a_n \text{sin}(n)$$ and $$b_n \text{cos}(n)$$ separately and use the arithmetic rules for limits of sequences to add them up to get $$0$$? I.e, $$-a_n \le a_n\text{sin}(n) \le a_n$$ and similarly for $$b_ncos(n)$$.
Answer:
Yes, you can do it separately.

For $$a_n$$sin(n)

$$-a_n\leq a_nsin(n)\leq a_n$$

For $$b_ncos(n)$$

$$-b_n\leq b_ncos(n)\leq b_n$$

Both are 0, then you can use limit rules to solve it.

You can either use squeeze or limit rules. For the sake of learning, you should try doing it with squeeze theorem.

The arithmetic rules for limits (aka "limit rules") theorem requires that $$\lim a_n$$ and $$\lim b_n$$ to exist before you can do $$\lim a_n b_n = \lim a_n \lim b_n$$.

Question:
Squeeze Theorem Question:

Hello, with squeeze theorem how do you know which limits to use on the side? I.e for both of these examples, how does one know the values have to be 6 and 8 or 1/n^2 and -1/n^2?
Answer:
Think of it like this:

For first example we start with cos($$n^2$$ + 7)

We know that $$-1\leq cos(n)\leq1$$. Note, we don't care what is inside cos

Add 7: $$6\leq cos(n)+7\leq 8$$

Divide by n

$$\frac{6}{n}\leq \frac{cos(n)+7}{n}\leq \frac{8}{n}$$

Example 2:

Start with $$(-1)^{n+1}$$. It is either -1 or 1

Hence: $$-1\leq(-1)^{n+1}\leq1$$

Divide by $$n^2$$

$$\frac{-1}{n^2}\leq \frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n^2}\leq\frac{1}{n^2}$$

Essentially, you need to find some function inside the equation that is guaranteed to have upper and lower bound. Then you can use them as the "anchor" to use the squeeze theorem.

Hope that helps!

Question:
Mobius week 3:

How could this be bounded below and not bounded at the same time? Is it due to the n that diverge when n is even?
Answer:
It's bounded below because the sequence can never go below 0.

And it's not bounded because $$a_n$$ diverges to infinity when n is even number. "Bounded" means "bounded above" and "bounded below" at the same time. In this question, for n is even, there is not an upper bound.

Question:
"convergent" or "divergent" and "bounded above" or "bounded below" and "monotonic":

I am just curious if there are some rules applied to the relationship between "convergent" or "divergent" and "bounded above" or "bounded below" and monotonicity.

I understand that from MCT, we have if an converges if and only if it is bounded above which means that we can interpret from either direction. Does this also indicate that this sequence is monotonic?
Answer:
Most of these are separate concepts.


For example, a sequence can be bounded below and diverge (e.g., $$a_n = n$$, or it converge (e.g., $$a_n = -\frac{1}{n}$$). Similarly for monotonic.

Question:
week3 Monotone Convergence Theorem:

__2023-09-25_15.30.38.png

Can someone explain these three true or false questions with explanations and examples? Thanks!
Answer:
For the first one you have to take into consideration MTC which says that if a sequence in bounded then it will converge.

Careful, a bounded sequence doesn't necessarily converge. For example, $$(-1)^n$$ is bounded (below by $$-1$$ and above by $$1$$) and diverges.

The MCT requires that a sequence be monotonic and bounded (either above or below depending on whether it's non-decr/non-incr) to conclude it converges.

Careful, a bounded sequence doesn't necessarily converge. For example, $(-1)^n$ is bounded (below by -1 and above by +1) and diverges.

The MCT requires that a sequence be monotonic and bounded (either above or below depending on whether it's non-decr/non-incr) to conclude it converges.

Question: General Question: If a sequence converges will the greatest lower bound always be the limit to infinity?
Answer: Not necessarily. Consider sequence $$a_n = -\frac{1}{n}$$ when n is odd, $$\frac{1}{n}$$ when n is even. $$glb(a_n)$$ would be -1. However, $$\lim_{n->\infty} a_n = 0$$

Question:
EP 5b:

I'm a little confused about how the last two steps prove that it is increasing. I understand everything up until then.
Answer:
By mathematical induction, if the base case holds and the inductive step also is proven to be true, then the original statement is true. 

In this case, we suppose $$0 < a_k < a_{k+1}$$ holds. In order for the inductive step to be true, we need to prove $$ 0 < a_{k+1} < a_{k+2}$$ holds as well. This is the standard format for proving the inductive hypothesis.

Question: Is 0 a natural number?: I'm getting tripped up over our definition of natural numbers in Math 137. Is 0 considered a natural number? I've been reviewing my notes because I'm getting confused but I can't find any explicit statements about it.
Answer:
No it is not For MATH 137, 0 is not natural number. 

However, 0 MAY BE natural numbers based on different context. For example, if we are talking about natural numbers based on Peano's axiom, then 0 is natural number. I believe some international standards also consider 0 as natural number. 

I think it is strange that somehow mathematics field doesn't not universally agree if 0 is natural number or not. But for this course, 0 is not natural number.

Question: QUIZ 3A (TF) Q2: The question was "If a sequence converges, then it is bounded" and the answer to that was "True". I have a little misconception about that. I thought a sequence could converge if it it was increasing and bounded above.(and not necessarily bounded below, making it non bounded). Wouldn't that mean that a convergent sequence does not have to be bounded?
Answer:
If a sequence converges, then we know there is an $$\epsilon > 0$$ such that aₙ$$\epsilon \left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$ (i.e. all of the rest of the function after some n is contained within this interval). This means you can just find the number that is the lowest for non-decreasing functions and call that the greatest upper bound (or highest for non-increasing functions, and say that's the lowest upper bound). I.e. there aren't an infinite number of points outside of this interval so surely one of them must be the lowest (or highest) (or in a case where aₙ is entirely contained within $$\left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$, just find the point in the interval or say $$L-\epsilon$$/$$L+\epsilon $$ is a lower bound/upper bound respectively).

So now we have identified both a greatest lower bound and lowest upper bound. Therefore, the function is bounded.

If a sequence converges, then we know for all $$\epsilon > 0$$ such that aₙ$$\epsilon \left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$ (i.e. all of the rest of the function after some n is contained within this interval). This means you can just find the number that is the lowest for non-decreasing functions and call that the greatest upper bound (or highest for non-increasing functions, and say that's the lowest upper bound). I.e. there aren't an infinite number of points outside of this interval so surely one of them must be the lowest (or highest) (or in a case where aₙ is entirely contained within $$\left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$, just find the point in the interval or say $$L-\epsilon$$/$$L+\epsilon $$ is a lower bound/upper bound respectively).

So now we have identified both a greatest lower bound and lowest upper bound. Therefore, the function is bounded.

If a sequence converges, then there is always an $$\epsilon > 0$$ such that aₙ$$\epsilon \left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$ (i.e. all of the rest of the function after some n is contained within this interval). This means you can just find the number that is the lowest for non-decreasing functions and call that the greatest upper bound (or highest for non-increasing functions, and say that's the lowest upper bound). I.e. there aren't an infinite number of points outside of this interval so surely one of them must be the lowest (or highest) (or in a case where aₙ is entirely contained within $$\left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$, just find the point in the interval or say $$L-\epsilon$$/$$L+\epsilon $$ is a lower bound/upper bound respectively).

So now we have identified both a greatest lower bound and lowest upper bound. Therefore, the function is bounded.

If a sequence converges, then there is always an $$\epsilon > 0$$ such that aₙ$$\epsilon \left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$ (i.e. all of the rest of the function after some n is contained within this interval). This means you can just find the number that is the lowest for non-decreasing functions and call that the greatest upper bound (or highest for non-increasing functions, and say that's the lowest upper bound). I.e. there aren't an infinite number of points outside of this interval so surely one of them must be the lowest (or highest).

So now we have identified both a greatest lower bound and lowest upper bound. Therefore, the function is bounded.

Question:
Alternate proof for week 4 practice question 2:

Hi, I realized my proof is slightly different from the answer, may I ask if this is valid as well? Thx!

Question: Let $$f(x) > 0$$ for all $$x \neq a$$ and assume limx→a
f(x) = L with L $$\neq$$±∞. Use the definition of limits
to show that L ≥ 0.

Pf:

We know $$|f(x)-L|<\epsilon$$ when $$0<|x-a|<\delta$$ for all $$\epsilon>0$$. Assume $$L<0$$. When $$f(x)>0$$, $$f(x)-L>0$$ so we can drop the absolute values to get $$f(x)-L<\epsilon$$. Now choose $$\epsilon =-L$$, which is greater than 0, then $$f(x)-L<-L$$ and $$f(x)<0$$, which is a contradiction, so $$L\geq0$$.
Answer: Looks good to me.

Question: Practice Problems Q2 - Choosing Epsilon Value: For question 2 in Quiz 4's Practice Problems, how do we know to choose epsilon = $$|L|/2$$?
Answer:
You can choose any epsilon as long as it is above 0. For that specific question you could pick: $$\frac{|L|}{4}$$ or $$\frac{|L|}{5}$$ or 6 and so on. The thing you are trying to contradict is that if f(x)>0 and L<0 cannot be true.

However, the reason why you choose $$\frac{|L|}{2}$$ is because L + $$\frac{|L|}{2}$$ is less than zero. That can't be since f(x) > 0.

Hope it helps ;)

Question: W4 Practice Problems Q1e: I'm not sure if I'm just not seeing something, but in Q4e of the practice problems, how do we know to choose delta as the minimum of 1 and $$36ε/7$$? Specifically, where are we deducing $$36ε/7$$ from?
Answer:
We proved that $$|\frac{x+3}{9x^2}| \leq \frac{7}{36}$$. We need to choose some number for |x-3| such that when multiplied, it equals epsilon.

Specifically, we established that $$2 \leq x \leq 4$$. Now 4 +3 = 7 and 9(2)(2) = 36. Therefore, we get $$\frac{7}{36}$$

We proved that $$|\frac{x+3}{9x^2}| \leq \frac{7}{36}$$. We need to choose some number for |x-3| such that when multiplied, it equals epsilon.

I'm a little confused how we can compute the limit of the sin function to equal 1 when x->2. I thought we only applied this rule when

x->0. Can someone please clarify?
Answer:
The solution didn't assume $$\lim_{x->2} \frac{sin (x)}{x} =1$$, it's still x-> 0.


Remember the variables are interchangeable. Let $$y = x^2 - 4$$. When x approaches 2, y approaches 0. then the limit becomes $$\lim_{y-> 0} \frac{sin (3y)}{3y}$$, which is 1.

Well if you are wondering why that goes to 1, then let z = 3y, and follow the steps above, you will get the original fundamental limit of trig :)

The solution didn't assume $$\lim_{x->2} \frac{sin (x)}{x} =1$$, it's still x-> 0.


Remember the variables are interchangeable. Let $$y = x^2 - 4$$. When x approaches 2, y approaches 0. then the limit becomes $$\lim_{y-> 0} \frac{sin (y)}{y}$$, which is 1.

Question:
Mob Quiz 4:

Why would these be wrong?
Answer:
For this question, we want to use the sequential characterization of limits, so we need a sequence $$x_n$$ that goes to 1 from the right when $$n\to \infty$$ and $$x_n \ne 1$$.

Choice 1 doesn't work as it approaches from $$1^-$$. When $$n$$ is small, we can see that $$x_n$$ is increasing, so it must approach 1 from the left ($$1^-$$), while we want a sequence that approaches from $$1^+$$ 

Choice 2 does not work because $$x_n = 1$$ which violates the definition of the theorem.

Choice 3 approaches 1 from the bottom. When n is smaller such as $$n= 1, 2, 3$$ the value of $$1- \frac{1}{n}$$ is closer to 0, and gets closer to 1 as the value of $$n$$ gets larger, so it approaches from $$1^-$$ while we want a sequence that approaches from $$1^+$$ as desired in the question and thus also does not work.

Choice 4 approaches zero (we can derive this using Squeeze Theorem), but we want a sequence that approaches 1 as n goes to infinity so it also doesn't work.

For this question, we want to use the sequential characterization of limits, so we need a sequence $$x_n$$ that goes to 1 from the right when $$n\to \infty$$ and $$x_n \ne 1$$.

Question:
Week 4 Practice Problem Q9:

Hi, can someone please explain to me how epsilon/3 is true. Thank you for your time!
Answer:
When you do your rough work/aside, you write |(3x-2)-14|<epsilon and get |3x-12|<epsilon. Factoring will find that you get

3|x-4|<epsilon. Divide both sides by 3 to get epsilon/3 as the largest possible delta value. Anything bigger (with a smaller denominator) will not work.

I also strongly recommend you to go over the practice question 1 all over again without help, cause if you try to prove $$\lim_{x->4}3x+2 = 14$$ normally using $$\epsilon - \delta$$ definition, you should get $$\frac{\epsilon}{3}$$ as your choice. o.o

Question:
Week 4 Quiz Problem 2:

Hi, I don't really know how we got the 3rd step in the solution as shown. Can someone please explain to me. Thanks!
Answer:
To use the fundamental trigonometric limit we will multiply the top/bottom by $$2\theta$$.

Then, we have $$\lim_\limits{\theta \to 0} \frac{sin\theta}{\cos\theta} \frac{1}{\sin(2\theta)}\frac{2\theta}{2\theta} = \lim_\limits{\theta \to 0} \frac{sin\theta}{\theta} \frac{2\theta}{\sin(2\theta)}\frac{1}{2\cos\theta}$$ by rearranging some of the numerators and denominators so we can use the fundamental trigonometric limit, $$\lim\limits_{\theta\to 0} \frac{sin\theta}{\theta} = 1$$. Since $$\cos\theta = 1$$ for $$\theta=0$$, then we get $$1\cdot 1\cdot \frac{1}{2(1)} = \frac{1}{2}$$ as desired.

Question:
Practice Problem 5, Question 4:

Hi, 

For the following question, 

For determining the interval, if the function was in fact continuous at x = 2 and x = -3, how would the interval change, for example, would I put square brackets instead?

Just to make sure my understanding is clear, is a function is only continuous if its limit and f(a) is the same?

Thank you in advance.
Answer:
If we were to re-define $$f(2) = \frac{4}{5} \cos(4)$$ then $$f(x)$$ would be continuous at $$x=2$$. You are correct that we would change the open bracket to a square bracket: $$(-3,2]\cup[2,\infty)$$. However, notice that this interval is the same thing as $$(-3,\infty)$$.

So, our final answer would be $$(-\infty, -3) \cup (-3,\infty)$$.


A function is continuous at $$x=a$$ if

$$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to a} f(x) $$ exists and $$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to a} f(x) = f(a)$$.

Question: Divergent limits of function: I'm slightly confused as to why it's for every M>0, what if there M you picked was below the limit of the function?
Answer:
Note that since the wording is "for every M > 0," it basically means "no matter what M > 0 you pick, f(x) will be greater past cutoff N." If f(x) is non-decreasing and approaches a limit, then that means that there must be an M > 0 that is above the limit (and thus is greater than f(x) to infinity), and hence it doesn't diverge to infinity.
Note that since the wording is "for every M > 0," it basically means "no matter what M > 0 you pick, f(x) will be greater past cutoff N." If f(x) is non-decreasing and approaches a limit, then that means that there must be an M > 0 that is above the limit (> f(x)), and hence it doesn't diverge to infinity.

Question: Proving discontinuities: Is there a formal way of proving the type of discontinuities and also a way to distinguish between them (holes, jumps and asymptote)
Answer:
I'm not sure necessarily of a formal way, but for example, if you have a jump discontinuity, then you would show that both $$\lim_{x\to a^{-}} f(x)$$ and $$\lim_{x\to a^{+}} f(x) $$ exist but do not equal. If you had a removable discontinuity, you would show that $$\lim_{x\to a} f(x)$$ exists but does not equal $$f(a)$$ and so on.
I'm not sure necessarily of a formal way, but for example, if you have a jump discontinuity, then you would show that both $$\lim_{x\to a^{-}} f(x)$$ and $$\lim_{x\to a^{+}} f(x) $$ exist but do not equal. Question:
question about definition of continuity:

I need some example to understand this definition. Could someone use this definition to prove that x/x is not continuous at x=0?

Thank you!
Answer:
For $$f(x) = \frac{x}{x}$$, we would just have $$f(0)$$ undefined, so $$f(x)$$ is discontinuous at $$x=0$$.

Here's another example: $$f(x) = \begin{cases} 0 \ \text{ if } x \neq 0 \\ 1 \ \text{ if } x = 0\end{cases}$$

To show that $$f(x)$$ is discontinuous at $$x=0$$, we just need to show the definition above doesn't hold for one value of $$\epsilon.$$

Let $$\epsilon = \frac{1}{2}$$, then notice that the inequality reads $$|f(x) - f(0)| = |0 - 1| = 1 \not < 1/2$$ for any $$\delta$$. In other words, there is no $$\delta$$ such that $$|x| < \delta$$ implies $$|f(x) - f(0)| < \frac{1}{2}$$, so the function is discontinuous at $$x=0$$.

Question:
Practice Problems W5, what are the Arithmetic Rules:

What are the rules it is referring to, and how are they used to show the function is continuous everywhere but at x=-3,2?
Answer:
Those are both theorems found in the course notes.

The Arithmetic Rules are properties such as

"if $$f(x)$$, $$g(x)$$ are continuous at $$x=a$$, then $$f+g$$ is continuous at $$x=a$$"
and so forth.

Continuity of composites lets us say that since $$x^2$$ and $$\cos(x)$$ are continuous on $$\mathbb{R}$$, then so is $$\cos(x^2)$$.

Question: Practice Problem W5 Q6: Should we assume that f(a+b) = f(a) + f(b)? Is this a rule we should remember?
Answer: This is not true in general. For example, if $$f(x) = x^2$$, then $$f(a+b) = a^2 + 2ab + b^2 \neq a^2 + b^2 = f(a) + f(b)$$. It is property only relevant to this particular question.

First year students on average have 5 courses, each with their own work load, and all harmoniously organized so that nothing overlaps and there is a balance. Moving the quiz to another day with disturb the schedule and cause more harm than good.

Question:
Question 4b Maliha Ahmed midterm review question:

The question is as follows:

Limit of x approaches 3 for : (sin(x^2-9))/(x-3)

I know this can turn into (sin((x-3)(x+3)))/(x-3) and then if I can turn this into the sin(x)/x identity I can work from there. I am just unsure how to go from

(sin((x-3)(x+3)))/(x-3) to the sin identity
Answer:
I'm going to make this question public as I think it's an interesting problem that other students may be interested in.

For $$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to3} \frac{\sin(x^2-9)}{x-3}$$, you have the right idea in trying to manipulate this into an FTL type question. However, modifying the argument of sin will probably not work. Can you think of a different operation you can perform to make this look like the FTL: $$\displaystyle \lim_{\theta \to 0} \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\theta}$$.

Question:
Quiz 3 Q1:

I am not sure why 0 is the upper bound. When n=3/2 (n $$\geq$$1) and sin($$\pi$$n)=-1, then its upper bound is 1.
Answer: When we are dealing with sequences, the $$n$$ has to be a positive integer, so we can not have $$n = \frac{3}{2}$$. So when $$n$$ is integer, we have that $$|\sin(n\pi)| = 0$$ for all $$n\in\mathbb{N}$$, so it is a constant sequence.

Question:
Strategy for evaluating limits at -infinity for functions:

Hello,

I am a bit confused on how to evaluate limits at -∞, usually when finding horizontal asymptotes. I get that we have strategies for +∞, such as dividing by x to the highest power, but I don't know any for -∞.

Take, for example, Q7 on the midterm review:

I evaluated the limit going to +∞ as 0, but I have no idea how to do the limit going to -∞.

I would appreciate it if I could get some help on how to tackle these kinds of questions.

Thank you
Answer:
In this case if $$x<-3$$, then $$|x^2-2x-15|=x^2-2x-15$$.

Therefore, the same must hold true for $$x\rightarrow -\infty$$.

So we have $$f(x)=\frac{x+3}{|x^2-2x-15|}=\frac{x+3}{(x+3)(x-5)}=\frac{1}{x-5}=\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}$$.

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty }\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}=0\cdot \frac{1}{1+0}=1\cdot1=0$$.

Generally speaking when solving limits at negative infinity, the process is quite similar to limits at positive infinity, you just have to keep an eye out for negative values in exponents, and the sign of your variables.

In this case if $$x<-3$$, then $$|x^2-2x-15|=x^2-2x-15$$.

Therefore, the same must hold true for $$x\rightarrow -\infty$$.

So we have $$f(x)=\frac{x+3}{|x^2-2x-15|}=\frac{x+3}{(x+3)(x-5)}=\frac{1}{x-5}=\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}$$.

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty }\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}=0\cdot \frac{1}{1+0}=1\cdot1=0$$.

Generally speaking when solving limits at negative infinity, the process is quite similar to limits at positive infinity, you just have to keep an eye out negative values in exponents, and the sign of your variables.

In this case if $$x<-3$$, then $$|x^2-2x-15|=x^2-2x-15$$.

Therefore, the same must hold true for $$x\rightarrow -\infty$$.

So we have $$f(x)=\frac{x+3}{|x^2-2x-15|}=\frac{x+3}{(x+3)(x-5)}=\frac{1}{x-5}=\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}$$.

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty }\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}=0\cdot \frac{1}{1+0}=1\cdot1=0$$.

Generally speaking when solving limits at negative infinity, the process is quite similar to limits at positive infity.

In this case if $$x<-3$$, then $$|x^2-2x-15|=x^2-2x-15$$.

Therefore, the same must hold true for $$x\rightarrow -\infty$$.

So we have $$f(x)=\frac{x+3}{|x^2-2x-15|}=\frac{x+3}{(x+3)(x-5)}=\frac{1}{x-5}=\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}$$.

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty }\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}=0\cdot \frac{1}{1+0}=1\cdot1=0$$.

Question:
Quiz 5A - Q4 (Continuity Application):

I might be misreading the question, but how do we know that this is true?
Answer: If f(x) is continuous at x=0, then we can conclude that $$\lim_{x->0} f(x) = f(0)$$. Note that when n->infinity, $$\frac{1}{n^2}$$ is also approaching 0. Thus the limit = f(0).

Question:
Quiz 4A - Q1 (Showing Limit DNE):

I'm wondering why b) is the solution and not a). My initial thought was to find a sequence that converges to infinity, but converges to a different value when f is applied to it. Does that not also answer the question?

Quiz 3A - Q2 (Definition of Non-Decreasing):

Terminology-wise, when we say that a function is non-decreasing, does that automatically make it monotonic? When looking at this question, I was thinking of something like the sine function, which is not decreasing + bounded above + not converging.

Is "not decreasing" different from "non-decreasing"?
Answer:
Well, when we claim a sequence is non-decreasing, it means that it's not decreasing throughout the entire sequence.

Sine function is not monotonic because it's neither non-decreasing nor non-decreasing. it's increasing at some part of the function and decreasing at some part of the function as well.

Question:
Question 5 Quiz 5A:

I tried solving this by assuming if x > 0 its continuous because its just a normal polynomial and then for x = 0 checking the left and right side limits. If you check them, the right is 2 and the left DNE. Doesn't this mean that f(x) is discontinuous at x = 0 and therefore not continuous on the interval [0, 1]?
Answer:
It’s a closed interval though, and for a function to be continuous on a closed interval [a,b] the right limit of a must equal the function value of a, the left limit of b must equal the function value of b, and the function must be continuous on the open interval (a,b). You’re right in saying the polynomial is continuous for x >0, and that satisfies the last condition. But because the interval is closed you really don’t have to check the left and right side limits of 0 for the statement to be true, just the right one, and the right limit at x= 0 is 2 which is also f(0). The left limit of 1 is 9, and f(1) is also 9, therefore the statement is true.
It’s a closed interval though, and for a function to be continuous on a closed interval [a,b] the right limit of a must equal the function value of a, the left limit of b must equal the function value of b, and the function must be continuous on the open interval (a,b). You’re right in saying the polynomial is continuous for x >0, and that satisfies the last condition. But because the interval is closed you really don’t have to check the left and right side limits of 0 for the statement to be true, just the right one, and the right limit at x= 0 is 2 which is also f(0). The left limit of 1 is 9, and f(1) is also 9, therefore the statement is true.

Question:
Practice Question 5 Question 8 e):

Why is part e false?
Answer: f(x) is periodic function in e), which means it repeats itself for every 4 units. So, in order for $$\lim_{x->\infty}f(x) = 4$$, x has to be 4 throughout the entire domain. However, that contradicts with $$\lim_{x->-\infty} f(x) = \infty$$. Thus false.

Question:
Quiz 4A Justification for this answer:

why is b correct?
Answer:
To show that the limit DNE, your aim is to find a sequence {xn} that converges to infinity, but the lim x-> inf sin(x) diverges.

a) xn = {Πn = {Π, 2Π, 3Π, ...}

b) xn = {Π/2, Π, 3Π/2, ...}

c) xn = {Π, Π/2, Π/3...}

Clearly, only a) and b) goes to infinity since c) goes to 0. Now, you want to see if f(xn) would converge/diverge for a/b.

a) f(xn) = {0,0,0,...}

b) f(xn) = {1,0,-1,0,...}

Since a) converges to 0 but b diverges, then you that b) would be the sequence to choose to show that the limit DNE.

Question:
Quiz 4A Q4:

Why is this true?
Answer: There's a theorem related to this. Basically, you're given that $$\lim_{x\to a} f(x)/g(x)$$ exists and that $$\lim_{x\to a} g(x) =0$$. This means that $$\lim_{x\to a}f(x)=0$$ too. For example, if $$\lim_{x\to a} f(x) = 1$$, then $$\lim_{x\to a} f(x)/g(x)$$ would not exist.

Question: Version B the first question: Could someone explain why the option c can't be used to show that cos(x) as x goes to infinity is DNE? And why others can?
Common mistake: Never thought about this. so for foundamental limit of trigonomietry sin(x)/x, top and bottom need to converge?
Answer: Yes, you can substitute 2/x with u. When x goes to 0, u goes to infinity. So by sequential characterization, this limit would be sin(u)/u as u goes to infinity which is different from the fundamental limit of trigonometry.  You can do it by Squeeze Theorem to get 0 instead.

Question:
Proof question:

How would we prove this question?
Answer:
If you know $$\{a_n\}$$ and $$\{b_n\}$$ converge (let's say to $$L$$ and $$M$$ respectively) then you can do a simple contradiction by assuming $$L > M$$ and building an $$\epsilon$$ interval around $$L$$ that will contain values of $$\{a_n\}$$ greater than $$b_n$$.

Knowing that $$\{a_n\}$$ is increasing allows you to state that it does in fact converge because it's bounded by $$b_1$$. A similar argument works for $$\{b_n\}$$.

Question:
bisection method:

for bisection method do stop at 2^(k+1) or 2^k? 

text book says k+1, my note says k.
Answer:
It really just depends on how you're measuring things. Ultimately you just need the final interval you are using to be no more than twice the length of the $$\epsilon$$.

For example if $$\epsilon = 0.1$$ then you just need to make sure your final interval is no bigger than $$0.2$$ units (since the root would be in the middle of the interval $$\pm 0.1$$.

Question: 2022 Midterm question 7: Why we are finding the limit of x approaches 0 for the first function in order to find c?
Answer:
Recall the definition of continuity at $$x=0$$ is that $$\displaystyle  \lim_{x\to0} f(x) = f(0)$$.

Since $$f(0) = c$$ we are required to calculate the limit of the other piece.

Try writing both as a piecewise, you'll see your work for $$|x-3|$$ is correct, but not for $$|3-x|$$

In particular, the $$\lim_{x\to 3^-} (|3-x|)$$ is not $$-(3-x)$$, it's actually just $$3-x$$

Same thing if you approach from the right, $$\lim_{x\to 3^+} (|3-x|)$$ is not $$3-x$$, it's $$-(3-x)$$

Try writing both as a piecewise, you'll see your work for $$|x-3|$$ is correct, but not for $$|3-x|$$

In particular, the $$\lim_{x\to 3^-} (|3-x|)$$ is not $$-(3-x)$$, it's actually just $$3-x$$

Same thing if you approach from the right, $$\lim_{x\to 3^+} (|3-x|)$$ is not $$3-x$$, it's $$-(3-x)$$

We can also notice that $$|3-x| = |-(x-3)| =  |x-3| $$. Thus the function in questions is just $$\frac{|x-3|}{|x-3|} = 1$$.

Is the fact that the lim as x->1- $$\neq$$ f(1) in the piecewise function enough to conclude that the function is discontinuous at x=1?

Or do we have to look at lim as x->1+ and show that the two limits do not equal?
Answer:
If either $$x \to a^+$$ or $$x \to a^-$$ does not equal $$f(a)$$ then it will have to be discontinuous. 

This follows from the one-side versus two-sided limits theorem (pg 77 of the notes) and the definition of continuity.

Question:
F22 Midterm Q12:

In terms of this solution, I understand everything up until the line before our concluding equation.

How do we deduce that $$ 0 < \frac{1}{\delta}< \frac{1}{x}$$, and why would that give us our final answer?
Answer:
If $$x \in (0, \delta)$$, then $$0 < x < \delta$$. So, the reciprocal, $$\frac{1}{x}$$, would be greater than $$\frac{1}{\delta}$$, which are both greater than $$0$$ since $$x, \delta > 0$$. So, if $$\delta = \frac{1}{N}$$ and $$x < \delta$$, then $$x < \frac{1}{N}$$. This means $$\frac{1}{x} > N$$, so $$\frac{1}{x}$$ is greater than the cutoff, thus the limit converges. 

This was my understanding, but there might be another interpretation.

Question: Value of delta: When proving the limit of a function using the fundamental definition of a limit of a function, why is delta made to be the minimum of a constant (usually 1) and a value involving epsilon? I would appreciate some clarification on this step of epsilon-delta proofs. Thank you.
Answer:
If you let delta to be less than some set value, then you can set a bound on x so that we can get a numeric value for some polynomials dependent on x. in Quiz 4 LA1's case it is $$\frac{3+x}{9x^2}$$. Otherwise your delta will be dependent on x and that would be invalid.

You can also choose other value instead of 1. Some people used $$\frac{1}{2}$$ for the bound. But 1 at most cases are easy to work with. I do want to note that if you choose value other than 1, your delta value will also change.

Question: Questions regarding to the limit calculation: For this question, I am not sure why does the limit exist. From my perspective, based on the sqrt(x) inside cos function, the limit will not exist when x approaches from the left side of 0 (which is shown clearly when we try to graph the function in desmos). __2023-10-24___12.43.34.png__2023-10-24___12.43.43.png
Answer:
You only consider x in the domain of the function, and in this case the square root of x is not defined for x < 0.

A more detailed explanation can be found here:

https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/637280/limit-of-sqrt-x-as-x-approaches-0#:~:text=Since%20the%20domain%20of%20f,and%20is%20equal%20to%200.

This is a good catch. You are correct that the answer should be DNE.

We are currently marking the midterms and will be accepting either answer as correct. Secondly, we will update the solutions to reflect this.

On the stackexchange article: for our purposes in MATH 137, we would take $$\lim_{x\to 0} \sqrt{x}$$ as DNE since the limit from below DNE as it is undefined.

Question: Question about derivative: since the definition of the derivative is $$\lim_{h\to0} \frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h} $$, if f(a) is not defined, we can immediately conclude that it is not differentiable at x=a right? Thank you
Answer: Yes. Another way to think about is that "differentiable implies continuous" and the contrapositive says "not continuous implies not differentiable." So, if the function is undefined at $$x=a$$, it is discontinuous, therefore not differentiable.

Question:
Finding Counterexamples:

Is there any strategy to coming up with counterexamples to disprove claims? Anything that would help with multiple choice questions. 

Thank you for the help!
Answer:
One way to practice this is to think about the theorems we've covered and consider things like:

  • the converse of theorem -- if it's not an iff, chances are that the converse is false
  • relax some of the hypotheses -- chances are, this will make the statement false

and come up with counterexamples related to those two above points.

Question:
Practice Problem 2 Week 6: <md>![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Flkqwd4cy25i5dq%2F3985bd3b754c63f67bf759bc4821f082c58bf10d35399091ec032418c35aaf8a%2Fimage.png)

![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Flkqwd4cy25i5dq%2F8a0b82c6e1ecbc9c8b650a5d3828317a029f1ecb9e73cb9daf7b77d926381536%2Fimage.png)

I am not sure on what I am doing wrong with my solution.</md>
Answer:
The derivative of (ax+b) is a since $$(ax+b)' = a(x)' +(b)'= a(1) + 0= a$$, and similarly, the derivative of (ax-b) is a, so the quotient rule becomes $$\frac{a(ax-b)-a(ax+b)}{(ax-b^2)}$$.
The derivative of (ax+b) is a, and the derivative of (ax-b) is a, so the quotient rule becomes $$\frac{a(ax-b)-a(ax+b)}{(ax-b^2)}$$.

Question: Question about limit derivatives:  Based on the result, I believe that the proof is incorrect? But could someone explain which step is wrong, thank you.
Answer:
It is not the case that $$f(x-h) = f(x+h)$$ (except for $$x=0$$).

If you think about this geometrically, $$f'(a) \approx \dfrac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}$$ for small $$h$$.

Now, if instead you do $$f(a-h)$$, you are effectively going "backwards" from $$f(a)$$. In the limit, you would effectively pick up a negative in front. One way to see this is to use the linear approximation: $$f(x) \approx f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)$$. Plug in both $$x=a+h$$ and $$x=a-h$$ and you should see a negative appear when isolating for $$f'(a)$$.

Question: general question: How can x times sin(1/x) at x=0 the left and right limit does not exist but the limit of it is 0?

The one-sided limits of $$x \sin (1/x)$$ do exist and evaluate to 0, so the limit exists. If we further defined the function to evaluate to 0 at $$x=0$$ then it would be continuous.

To show those one-sided limits, you would need to use the squeeze theorem; one cannot state that 0 x DNE is 0 since the limit rules do not apply.

Question:
Week 6 Quiz question:

Why should I use squeeze theorem at the end of solution?
Answer:
You reach a point when solving the question where you cannot proceed with traditional algebraic reasoning, so you have to use alternative methods such as the squeeze theorem.

It seems like you would like to use the arithmetic rules for limits, i.e., you want to do $$\lim_{h\to0} h \sin(1/h) = \lim_{h\to0} h \lim_{h\to0} \sin(1/h) = 0$$, however, you CANNOT apply the limit rules unless both limits exist on their own.

Here, $$\lim_{h\to0} \sin(1/h)$$ DNE so you cannot apply the limit rules. Hence the need for the squeeze theorem.

Question:
Practice questions Q3 week 7:

For part b of Q3 of the week 7 practice questions, why did we chooe a=7 and a=pi for the 2 estimates?
Answer: From $$3a)$$, we know that the formula for the sequence generated by the polynomial $$x^2-a$$ is $$x_{n+1} = \frac{1}{2} (x_n + \frac{a}{x_n})$$. The polynomial $$f(x)  =x^2-a$$ has roots $$x = \pm \sqrt{a}$$, so if we want to find the approximation for $$\sqrt{7}$$, we can let $$a=7$$ and then perform Newton's method where the first step is $$x_1 = 3$$ as given by the question, then $$x_2 = \frac{1}{2} (x_1 + \frac{7}{x_n1}) = \frac{1}{2}(3+\frac{7}{3}) \approx 2.66667$$, etc.

Question:
question about trig power:

if $$cos^{2}(x) = (cos(x))^{2}$$, why can't we also say that  $$cos^{-1} (x)= (cos(x))^{-1} $$ ? Why doing the same step will caused error for -1 which leads  $$arccos(x) = cos^{-1}(x) =  \frac{1}{cos(x)} = sec(x)$$.

Thank you
Answer:
The notation $$\cos^{-1}(x)$$ is ambiguous: it could mean $$\arccos(x)$$ or it could mean $$\frac{1}{cos(x)}$$.

Thus, we use $$\arccos(x)$$ to denote the inverse function of cosine and $$\sec(x)$$ to denote the reciprocal of cosine. Note that $$\arccos(x) \neq \sec(x)$$, i.e., these are two different functions.

Question:
Why is this log rule true?:

I've heard this being referred to as the change of base rule. Would appreciate an explanation as to why it is true.
Answer:
$$log_a(x) = y$$

$$a^y = x$$

Since, $$a = b^{log_b(a)}$$

So, $$a^y = b^{log_b(a)⋅y} = x$$

Taking $$log_b$$ on both sides, $$log_b(b^{log_b(a)⋅y}) = log_b(x)$$

$$log_b(a)⋅y = log_b(x)$$ 

$$y = \frac{log_b(x)}{log_b(a)}$$

Since, $$y = log_a(x)$$

Therefore, $$log_a(x) = \frac{log_b(x)}{log_b(a)}$$

This proof is generic for any base $$b$$. If you let $$b = e$$, the result will equal to the one you have put above, i.e. $$log_a(x) = \frac{ln(x)}{ln(a)}$$

$$log_a(x) = y$$

$$a^y = x$$

Since, $$a = b^{log_b(a)}$$

So, $$a^y = b^{log_b(a)⋅y} = x$$

Taking $$log_b$$ on both sides, $$log_b(b^{log_b(a)⋅y}) = log_b(x)$$

$$log_b(a)⋅y = log_b(x)$$ 

$$y = \frac{log_b(x)}{log_b(a)}$$

Since, $$y = log_a(x)$$

Therefore, $$log_a(x) = \frac{log_b(x)}{log_b(a)}$$

This proof is generic for any base $$b$$. If you let $$b = e$$, the result will equal to the one you have put above, i.e. $$ln(x) = \frac{ln(x)}{ln(a)}$$

You can find videos online showing the proof if you want to.

Question:
Newtons method limitations:

Hello,

I was reading through some course notes and found that newton's method can sometimes not work because if you pick a point too far from the root, the sequence may diverge.

Answer:
The iterations are a recursive sequence: $$x_{n+1} = x_n - \dfrac{f(x_n)}{f'(x_n)}$$ with an initial value $$x_1$$. Hence we can talk about the sequence $$\{x_n \}$$ converging or diverging.

We're getting further away from the root and it will never converge to anything.

Question: Long Answer Questions on Quizzes: Hi, this is a general question, but I am wondering on quizzes, if we get the correct answer on the long answer questions but our work is not correct, or we used a different method than we were meant to would we still get full marks, considering we found the correct answer? Or will we get marks taken off if some of our work is incorrect. Thanks.
Answer:
Generally yes, as long as the different method is valid. If the method is invalid, then it is possible there may be a part-mark for a correct final answer (but this is not always the case).

For example, on one of the previous quizzes, there was a question of the form $$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0} x^2 \sin(\frac{1}{x})$$ and many students used the limit rules to show the limit to be 0. However, the limit rules cannot be applied since the limit of $$\sin(\frac{1}{x})$$ DNE and hence one needs to use the squeeze theorem. So applying the limit rules would not result in full points.

Question: linear function definition: In Math137, is a constant function considered a linear function?
Answer:
A polynomial is of the form $$p(x) = c_n x^n + c_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \dots + c_1 x + c_0$$ where $$c_i \in \mathbb{R}$$. Because of this, we can pick $$c_i = 0$$ except $$c_0$$ so a constant function would be a polynomial.

By the same logic, a linear function is of the form $$y = ax + b$$ where $$a,b \in \mathbb{R}$$ and we can take $$a=0$$ and say that any constant is also a linear function.

Question: Week 8 practice question 7: Could anyone explain what's being said in the solution that the derivative of the function is not equal to 0 so it is not possible to have 2 or more values that makes f(x) = 0. Why is this?
Answer:
Consider mean value theorem. When we say the function has two roots, that means there exists 2 values of x, $$x_1$$ and $$x_2$$ such that $$f(x_1) = f(x_2) = 0$$. Which, by MVT, we should be able to find a value $$c$$ between $$x_1$$ and $$x_2$$ such that f'(c) = 0.

However, since $$ f'(x) > 0,  \forall x \in \mathbb{R}$$, that means there is no such $$c$$ that f'(c) = 0. Which means there is no way to have more than 2 roots. Consider mean value theorem. When we say the function has two roots, that means there exists 2 values of x, $$x_1$$ and $$x_2$$ such that $$f(x_1) = f(x_2) = 0$$. Which, by MVT, we should be able to find a value $$c$$ between $$x_1$$ and $$x_2$$ such that f'(c) = 0.

However, since f'(x) > 0 for all x belongs to real, that means there is no such $$c$$ that f'(c) = 0. Which means there is no way to have more than 2 roots.

Question: Roots and Derivative: Do the number of roots a function has have ant correlation with the number of critical points
Answer:
It's an interesting idea!

Sadly, there is no correlation. For example, you could have a function with an infinite number of critical points but no roots, e.g. $$\sin(x) + 2$$, or it could have no critical points and still have a root, e.g., $$\frac{1}{x} - 1$$.

Question:
ep diff and cts functions:

Why is the first one false the second true?
Answer:
10.  False because nothing indicates that the function is differentiable in the interval (continuity does not imply differentiability)

11. True because the function is differentiable everywhere in the interval, so continuous everywhere (differentiability implies continuity), and f(a)=f(b), so by Rolles Theorem f'(c)=0 for some c in [a,b] 10.  False because nothing indicates that the function is differentiable in the interval. 

11. True because the function is differentiable everywhere in the interval, so continuous everywhere (differentiability implies continuity), and f(a)=f(b), so by Rolles Theorem f'(c)=0 for some c in [a,b]

For 10, you can imagine a counter example of $|x|$ (appropriately shifted and scaled to satisfy the conditions in the problem).

One thing to point out about 11 is that it talks about differentiability on a closed interval and this is something that we haven't discussed in 137. For our purpose (at least in our course notes), we only talk about differentiability on an open interval. This is because the definition of differentiable: $$f'(a) = \lim_{h\to0} \frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}$$ is only doable on an open interval (since we'd need $$h\to0^+$$ and $$h\to0^-$$).

Question:
Are endpoints differentiable and do global extrema at a point b also lead to f'(a) = 0 or f'(a) DNE?:

I was wondering this because I was trying to determine if global extrema also have f'(x) = 0 or f'(x) DNE?

I understand that global extrema are also local extrema, except the ones at the endpoints, so it should be true in the case when global extrema are within an open interval, but what about global extrema at the endpoints of a closed interval?

Thanks!
Answer:
The function isn't necessarily differentiable at the endpoints (since the endpoints are not contained within (a,b)) so the derivative does not equal 0. Technically since you're assuming x is within [a,b] (i.e. don't know values < a or > b), you could say the derivative does not exist at the endpoints (careful though since some functions are differentiable on ℝ but we're interested in x within [a,b]).

Question:
Logarithmic Differentiation: When to use absolute values?:

The difference in the answers of (a) and (b) lie in the restriction x>0 and the lack of restriction on (b). So is it true that whenever a restriction such as x>0 is not given, we should absolute |y| before differentating?

When graphed, this function does not exist for the negative side anyways. Either way, my question is: if theres no restriction x>0, should we always write |y|?
Answer:
I think it depends on what you’re trying to differentiate. With the given restriction, we can apply ln to both sides in part a) and not have any issues. However, in b), if we ln both sides then the derivative doesn’t make sense for negative x. So, we use abs Val to resolve that issue. 

You could have a situation where there is no restriction but you don’t need to do anything special: ie: $$y=(x^2+1)^{2x}$$, since $$ln(x^2+1)$$ exists $$\forall x\in \mathbb{R}$$. 

Bottom line, I believe it depends on the question, not whether it’s restricted. Usually we want to avoid abs Val because it can be annoying to work with. 
I think it depends on what you’re trying to differentiate. With the given restriction, we can apply ln to both sides in part a) and not have any issues. However, in b), if we ln both sides then the derivative doesn’t make sense for negative x. So, we use abs Val to resolve that issue. 

You could have a situation where there is no restriction but you don’t need to do anything special: ie: $$y=(x^2+1)^{2x}$$, since $$ln(x^2+1)$$ exists $$/forall x/in /mathbb{R}$$. 

Bottom line, I believe it depends on the question, not whether it’s restricted. Usually we want to avoid abs Val because it can be annoying to work with.

Question:
Week 9 Practice Problem 7:

Hi, 

For the following question

How did they determine the following inequalities

$$x + sin(x)cos(x) \geq x-1$$. 

$$f(x)e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{x-1}{e}$$

Thank you for your time.
Answer:
Consider sin(x)cos(x). Note that both sin(x) and cos(x)'s range are [-1, 1], then we can say $$-1 \leq sin(x)cos(x) \leq 1$$, which leads to $$x-1 \leq x+ sin(x)cos(x) \leq x+ 1$$, which we can conclude $$f(x) \geq x-1$$.

Now, also because $$-1 \leq sin(x) \leq 1$$, then $$\frac{1}{e} \leq e^{sin(x)} \leq e$$, which $$e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{1}{e}$$. Multiply $$f(x) \geq x-1$$ to the inequality, we can get $$f(x)e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{x-1}{e}$$.

Consider sin(x)cos(x). Note that both sin(x) and cos(x)'s range are [-1, 1], then we can say $$-1 \leq sin(x)cos(x) \leq 1$$, which leads to $$x-1 \leq x+ sin(x)cos(x) \leq x+ 1$$, which we can conclude $$f(x) \geq x-1$$.

Now, also because $$-1 \leq sin(x) \leq 1$$, then $$\frac{1}{e} \leq e^{sin(x)} \leq e$$, which $$e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{1}{e}$$. Multiply $$f(x) \geq x-1$$. to the inequality, we can get $$f(x)e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{x-1}{e}$$.

Question:
Question about continuity and limit operations.:

Could some prove why if the function is continuous, the following operation is allowed.

$$lim_{x\to\infty} ln(\frac{51x}{x+7} )= ln( \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{51x}{x+7})$$

By the way, does both function need to be continuous for this operation, or only the outer function is continuous (ln) will be sufficient for this operation.

thank you
Answer:
I'm certainly not up to the challenge of proving this for you, but I can offer some insights as to why it's true. In the Course Notes, [Thm 11: Sequential Characterization of Limits] and [Thm 15: Continuity of compositions] show that the limit of a sequence that approaches $$\infty$$ and is equal to $$a$$ is also equal to $$f(a)$$. You can also look at the proof of Thm 15 in lecture slides (One example is Lec 14 006_Kotecha (Continuity), which you can find under instructor content).

In terms of your second question, I think only the outer one needs to be continuous, then you can examine the inner limit and see whether it exists or not. In this case, the inner function would be discontinuous at $$x=-7$$ but I'm not sure if that matters since we want $$x\to\infty$$. The inner function might need to be continuous for $$x$$ near to $$a$$.

Would appreciate an instructor's insights on this question as well.

The student answer is correct.

For a composition of functions, $$h(x) = g(f(x))$$, you need $$f$$ to be continuous at $$a$$ and $$g$$ to be continuous $$f(a)$$ and then you can conclude that $$h(x)$$ is also continuous at $$x=a$$.

Question: Practice 9 Q7d: Hi, i cannot understand how can we get the value of x when g'(x) = 0. Can someone explain, please?
Answer: We examine $$g'(x) = 2\cos^2(x)e^{\sin(x)} + (x + \sin(x)\cos(x))\cos(x)e^{\sin(x)}$$. We're looking for where $$g'(x)=0$$. Not sure if there's a more systematic approach to doing this, but observe that both terms contain a $$\cos(x)$$ and an $$e^{\sin(x)}$$. Since $$e^{\sin(x)} > 0 \;\;\forall x \in \mathbb{R}$$, the easiest way to have $$g'(x)=0$$ is to let $$\cos(x)=0$$, which we know is true when $$x=\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3\pi}{2}...$$ otherwise expressed as $$x=\frac{(2k +1)\pi}{2}$$ for any $$ k\in\mathbb{N}$$

Question:
To use IFT, does the function on the interval need to be continuous or differentiable:

Just wanted to confirm.

I assume the answer is no for continuity and yes for differentiability because IFT works if f'(x) is > (or >=, <, <=) for all x in the interval. This would mean that the function must differentiable across the whole interval, but that doesn't necessarily mean that the function must be continuous throughout.

Is that correct?

Thanks in advance!
Answer:
When you say IFT, are you referring to Inverse Function Theorem or Increasing Function Theorem?

For Inverse, f has to be continuous and differentiable on the shown intervals.

For Increasing, the fact that we assume $$f'(x)>0 \;\;\; \forall x\in I$$ implies that $$f(x)$$ is differentiable $$\forall x\in I$$ and therefore $$f(x)$$ is continuous $$\forall x\in I$$. (Differentiability implies continuity / you can't differentiate a discontinuous function).

Bottom line is, with either theorem the function must be differentiable across the interval, which automatically means that it is also continuous, since differentiability implies continuity.

Hope that helps!

There are two cases:

Question: Proof Question: "Let" vs "If": What's the difference between using the word "Let" vs "If" to specify something in a proof? Are they synonyms? For example from a sequence limit proof: "Let ε > 0 be given. Let N > 2ε/9, N ∈ N. Then, if n ≥ N , we get..."? Can we just say let ε > 0, let N ∈ N, let N > 2ε/9, let n ≥ N?
Answer:
Well there is a difference in proof.

"Let" is more used if you want to define something. It also has similar meanings with "assume" or "suppose". You can consider it as setting a variable in programming languages. Usually if you used "let", then the things defined by "let" is considered to be true. 

You start something with "if" in the proof if you want to start an implication. This is the same logic as the "if" statement in programming languages. You want to use "if" to set up a condition or a conclusion, which if a condition is satisfied, then something will be met. Note that the condition after "if" may not be true.

(This is out of the scope of MATH 137 but in CS245/PMATH 330 you will learn more about truth table which "if A then B" means A->B, which also means A implies B, A and B are condition(s) here. You will understand more in depth about if/implication)

Question:
practice questions week 10 Q8c:

I'm confused what they even mean by this question
Answer:
That notation is saying "the sum of the function values at each of the local extrema is equal to 0". So what you have to do is find the local extrema (you should find there are 2: a local min at $$-\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}$$ and a local max at $$\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}$$, you can easily verify this on desmos). Then, you take the function values of those extrema (ie: plug $$-\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}$$ and $$\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}$$ into the original function) and add those results together. You should find the sum is 0, thus this statement is true. 

You might want a calculator, especially for doing the derivative tests and plugging in the extrema into the function. 

Let me know if you want more clarification on the steps I took!

Question: Concept: Why can't constant function have inflection points?
Answer:
Graphically, a constant function is just a horizontal line, so it is neither increasing nor decreasing, nor does it have any concavity. So, no poi where concavity changes.

In terms of calculus, when you take the first derivative of a constant function, you get 0. Then, you take the second derivative and also get 0. So there's no concavity (where f''(x)>0 or <0), so concavity can't change and result in a poi.

Question:
Quiz 2 Question: Epsilon-N Proof:

So from talking to the instructors it seems like this proof

should work as an Epsilon-N proof for this question but looking at the official solution

I am still struggling to understand whether or not I am allowed to put the highlighted "$$<\epsilon$$" in that step without ruining the proof. I do not want to incorrectly assume the conclusion in the first step of my proof but it still looks like if I were to plug $$\frac{3\epsilon +2}{9\epsilon }$$ into N for $$|\frac{2N}{3N-1}-\frac{2}{3}|$$, it would still evaluate to $$\epsilon$$ just as it does with $$\frac{2}{9N-3}$$ as in the official solution, so I don't understand how it could be a false statement to say $$|\frac{2N}{3N-1}-\frac{2}{3}|<\epsilon$$?

TLDR does the highlighted "$$<\epsilon$$" break my proof?
Answer:
I would say yes, that is an issue because you are assuming the conclusion at the beginning of your proof. 

Basically, you shouldn't assume that $$|a_n - L |< \epsilon$$ at the beginning. Instead, you should derive this relationship in your calculation and your choice for $$N$$.

In the posted solution, notice that we start with $$|a_n - L|$$ and do a series of simplifications to get to $$|a_n - L| = \frac{2}{9n-3}$$.

Then, since $$n \geq N$$, we have $$\frac{2}{9n-3} \leq \frac{2}{9N-3}$$.

Finally, since we picked $$N>\frac{1}{9} (\frac{2}{\epsilon} + 3)$$, this means $$\frac{2}{9N-3} < \epsilon$$ (after simplification).

The main point is that the logical structure of the proof is important. You start with $$|a_n-L|$$ and then show that your choice of $$N$$ leads to a $$<\epsilon$$ at the end.

Does f have to be continuous at x = 0 for it to be an inflection point, or can it just be in the domain with f''(0) = 0 or DNE? 

Thank you for the help!
Answer:
I think it has to be continuous at that point. Here's the definition from the textbook:

When you say "in the domain with f''(0) = 0 or DNE" I assume you're referring to endpoints and/or jump discontinuities? In either of those cases, you would not be able to assess the concavity of at least one side, so you would not be able to conclude that concavity changes.

Question:
Test for inflection points:

if the f''(x) doesnt exist at x=c then its not continuous at x=c as well right (since differentiability implies continuity)? so at x=c then there shouldn't be an inflection point by this logic as well right? From the weekly outline problems , why does f have a inflection point at x=0 (because in part b we showed that f''(x) doesn't exist at x=0)?
Answer: Differentiability implies continuity but not being differentiable doesn't imply not being continuous. The derivative can not exist at x = c and the function can still be continuous there.
